item.title: The Lure of a Rising Asian Metropolis? No Traffic.
item.description: Indonesia is building a new, green city in the jungle. Its future is far from certain, but new residents like living there.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ulet Ifansasti

media:content.media:description: The wings statue at Kusuma Bangsa Park in Nusantara, with the presidential palace and government ministry buildings in the background, at Penajam North Paser Regency in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, in November.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Social Media Causing Worry For Parents Around Globe
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 27, 2025.

item.title: Guinea Goes to Polls as Ruling Junta Seeks Legitimacy
item.description: Whoever wins faces the daunting task of feeding the West African country’s poor and navigating the interests of global powers seeking critical minerals, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh

media:content.media:description: A supporter dressed as Mamady Doumbouya traveling with armed escorts in Conakry, Guinea, on Thursday.

item.description: Nusantara is surrounded by forest.

item.title: Families Demand Answers a Year After Deadliest Plane Crash in South Korea
item.description: Many details of the Jeju Air disaster that killed 179 people remain unclear despite multiple investigations by officials and protests by the victims’ families.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and John Yoon

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The wreckage of Jeju Air Flight 2216 late last year at the Muan International Airport in Muan, South Korea.

item.title: As Some Boycott Myanmar’s Flawed Election, Others Hope for Change
item.description: The voting for Parliament is almost sure to favor the ruling military junta, which is stage-managing the polls. Still, some see them as the most pragmatic way to try to improve conditions.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

media:content.media:description: Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, the Myanmar army’s commander in chief, voting at a polling station in Naypyitaw, Myanmar, on Sunday.

item.title: No Corrections: Dec. 28, 2025
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 28., 2025.

item.title: The Year in Lists
item.description: As the year drew to a close, we reached out to Opinion columnists and contributors for personal lists.

item.title: Ski Slopes Are Empty as a Labor Dispute Shuts Down Telluride, Colo.
item.description: Now, vacationers looking to ski are wondering what to do and merchants are hoping it doesn’t last.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

media:content.media:credit: William Woody for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Members of the Telluride Professional Ski Patrol Association picketed on Saturday to demand higher pay.

item.description: A training video for drivers, supplied by Uber.
A training video for drivers, supplied by Uber.

item.title: Off Broadway Musicals
item.description: An Alex Eaton-Salners puzzle on a Sunday? Jazz hands!
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Sutton Foster, center, as Reno Sweeney in Cole Porter’s ”Anything Goes,” which takes place on a boat, in the ocean.

item.title: Joseph Hartzler Dies at 75; Led Prosecution of Oklahoma City Bomber
item.description: He and his team secured the conviction of Timothy McVeigh, who in 1995 committed the deadliest domestic terror attack in American history.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:description: Joseph Hartzler, the lead prosecutor at Timothy McVeigh’s trial for the Oklahoma City bombing, arriving in 1997 at the federal courthouse in Denver, where the trial took place. Mr. Hartzler had multiple sclerosis and used a motor scooter.

item.title: New York City Hit With Heaviest Snowfall in Years
item.description: A winter storm blanketed the Greater New York area, leading to more than 400 flight cancellations across the region’s major airports. Parts of Long Island saw up to nine inches of snow.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

item.title: Gary Graffman, Piano Virtuoso and Renowned Teacher, Dies at 97
item.description: Mr. Graffman was a onetime child prodigy whose career was curtailed by a neurological condition that restricted him to his left hand.
item.dc:creator: Vivien Schweitzer

media:content.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gary Graffman in 2018, when he turned 90. He was an acclaimed concert pianist before developing focal dystonia, the neurological disorder that restricted him to his left hand, in his 50s.

item.title: Mickey Lee, a ‘Big Brother’ Contestant, Dies at 35
item.description: Ms. Lee, a party host in Atlanta, died from multiple cardiac arrests brought on by the flu, according to a social media post.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:description: Mickey Lee, an event curator in Atlanta, competed in the latest season of “Big Brother” on CBS.

item.title: A Second Lawsuit Accuses Tyler Perry of Sexual Assault
item.description: Mario Rodriguez, who had a role in one of Mr. Perry’s films, sued him on Thursday, months after another actor filed a similar lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Mark Walker

media:content.media:description: The actor and director Tyler Perry was named as a defendant in a sexual harassment lawsuit filed on Thursday in California.

item.title: How Oil, Drugs and Immigration Fueled Trump’s Venezuela Campaign
item.description: New details of deliberations show how aides with overlapping agendas drove the United States toward a militarized confrontation with Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager, Charlie Savage, Julian E. Barnes and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, left, and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, right, have been key players, alongside the presidential adviser Stephen Miller, in President Trump’s escalating conflict in Venezuela.

item.title: Hundreds of Flights Canceled at New York Airports, Even With a Few Inches of Snow
item.description: To avoid the ripple effects of real-time adjustments to what was predicted to be up to nine inches of snow, the major airlines said they pre-emptively canceled flights.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

media:content.media:description: Kennedy International Airport on Saturday morning. The airport, along with LaGuardia and Newark International, dealt with hundreds of flight cancellations and delays from Friday into Saturday.

item.title: Girl, 4, Dies After Being Found Unconscious in the Bronx
item.description: An autopsy is being conducted to find the cause of death of the girl, whose name has not been released. The police have made no arrests.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Police officers responding to a 911 call found the girl in a building in Allerton in the Bronx, a law enforcement official said.

item.title: Two Times Journalists Join an Expedition to Antartica
item.description: Our journalists are joining scientists on a research ship sailing to the continent’s fast-melting glaciers.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Raymond Zhong, a Times climate reporter, at Lyttelton Harbour, New Zealand, on Thursday. He’s sailing to Antarctica aboard the research icebreaker Araon.

item.title: Map: 6.6-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Taiwan
item.description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
item.dc:creator: William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, Joey K. Lee and Bea Malsky

item.title: She Studied the Health Effects of Wildfires, Until the E.P.A. Cut Her Grant
item.description: Marina Vance had an E.P.A. grant to help homeowners counter the impact of wildfire smoke, until the agency deemed the research “no longer consistent” with its priorities.
item.dc:creator: Interview by Carl Zimmer

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Brenner for The New York Times

item.title: Air Fryer Salmon and More of Our Best Air Fryer Recipes
item.description: Salmon fillets, chicken wings, green beans and broccoli all cook to quick perfection with these trusted air-fryer recipes.
item.dc:creator: Mia Leimkuhler

media:content.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.
media:content.media:description: Eleanore Park’s air-fryer salmon.

item.title: Trump Pursues His Legacy One Name at a Time
item.description: In attaching his name to buildings and programs while still president, Donald Trump is walking a path paved by conquerors and autocrats.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Purdy
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump announcing the Navy’s new “Trump Class” battleships.

item.title: 7 preguntas que debes hacerte para ser más feliz en 2026
item.description: Es hora de mirar hacia atrás… y hacia delante.

item.title: Sesame Scallion Buns, and More Savory Bakes
item.description: Because I’m sugared out, but I still want the warmth and aroma of golden dough baking in the oven.

media:content.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.
media:content.media:description: Genevieve Ko’s sesame scallion buns.

item.title: Saudi-Led Group in Yemen Tells Separatists to Withdraw, or Be ‘Dealt With’
item.description: The Saudis ramped up their rhetoric against a faction that has seized parts of Yemen in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar and Adam Rasgon

media:content.media:description: Forces affiliated with Yemen’s separatist Southern Transitional Council in Abyan, Yemen, this month.

item.title: What ‘No Other Choice’ Reveals About the Humiliation of Work
item.description: A Korean film resonates in a moment when America has its highest unemployment rate since 2021.

item.title: In Which I Try Valiantly to Cheer You Up
item.description: OK, 2025 wasn’t the best year ever. But we’re arguably still in the best decade in the history of humanity.

item.title: I Love My Naturally Aging Face
item.description: But when I see Demi Moore, 63, looking far younger than me at 48, I wonder if I should be figuring out a way to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Marisa Meltzer

item.title: Sal Khan: A.I. Will Displace Workers at a Scale Many Don’t Realize
item.description: Companies benefiting from A.I. should donate a small percentage of their profits to retrain the workers the tech will displace.
item.dc:creator: Sal Khan

item.title: Climate Goals Are Becoming More Realistic. That’s Good News.
item.description: Policymakers and investors are pursuing what’s feasible rather than promising the impossible.
item.dc:creator: David G. Victor

item.title: At Protests, Lots of Boomers, Few Young People. Why?
item.description: A guest essay offered several possible explanations. Young and older readers offer their own.

item.description: This week, we close out the year with your best advice of 2025.

item.description: Every year, I choose a university student to accompany me on a reporting trip.

item.title: A Sweeping Look at One Thing That Unites Canada: Winter
item.description: The National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa has a major exhibition of 164 works from around the world depicting winter and the place of people and animals within it.

media:content.media:description: Jean-François Bélisle with “Winter Woodland” by Lawren S. Harris.

item.title: New York Receives Its Heaviest Snowfall in Nearly 4 Years, Disrupting Flights
item.description: Central Park got more than four inches of snow for the first time since January 2022, with higher totals outside New York City.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman and Christopher Maag

item.title: En Venezuela, la historia de un bloqueo parece repetirse
item.description: Una crisis de hace más de un siglo involucró a un dictador aficionado a la fiesta, los objetivos estadounidenses de afirmar su supremacía militar, y fricciones entre las grandes potencias.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

media:content.media:description: Cipriano Castro, quien gobernó Venezuela de 1899 a 1908. Conocido como el “León de los Andes”, desafió a las grandes potencias de la época.

item.title: James Cameron deja atrás los estallidos en la nueva película de ‘Avatar’
item.description: El director de la exitosa saga reflexiona sobre el paso del tiempo, el liderazgo y el autocontrol. “Ya no grito”, dijo.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

media:content.media:credit: JJ Geiger para The New York Times

item.title: Reseña de ‘Marty Supremo’: la lucha de Timothée Chalamet
item.description: El actor interpreta a un magnético y afanoso campeón de tenis de mesa en la nueva película de Josh Safdie, una de las más emocionantes del año.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

media:content.media:description: Timothée Chalamet en Marty Supremo, ambientada en el Nueva York de 1952 y dirigida por Josh Safdie con un pulso electrizante.

item.title: La venganza de la complaciente
item.description: Después de vivir una agresión sexual, trabajé durante años para hacerme invisible. Pero Ryan me vio de todos modos.
item.dc:creator: Kimberley Falk

item.title: How ‘Marty Supreme’ Got Ping Pong Right
item.description: The director Josh Safdie had a personal connection to 1950s players, but he also enlisted professionals to choreograph the action and employed a visual trick.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: For a Night at the Museum, Pajamas and Dinosaurs
item.description: Roaming the American Museum of Natural History in pajamas made for a night to remember for hundreds of children and their brave parents.
item.dc:creator: Vidhya Nagarajan and Sarah Bahr

item.title: A Dancing Dictator and Bankers in Chains: The Other Venezuela Blockade
item.description: A crisis more than a century ago involved U.S. aims to assert military supremacy, a hard-partying dictator and frictions among the great powers.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

media:content.media:description: Cipriano Castro, who ruled Venezuela from 1899 to 1908. Known as the “Lion of the Andes,” he defied the great powers of the era.

item.title: Journey to the Melting Continent
item.description: The New York Times is joining an expedition by sea to Antarctica’s fastest-thinning glaciers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
